title: Was Lenin really a communist or just a power hungry opportunistic tyrant, who just wants to expand his own power as Chomsky states? - Quora

response.answer_text: Lenin was dedicated all his life to Marxist politics and its communism aim, as he interpreted it. The defeat of the workers revolution in Russia was peculiar in that this defeat came from the revolutionary forces themselves, it was internal to the program and action of the Bolsheviks. They were state socialists — with the leadership drawn from the intelligentsia — and they didn’t really understand adequately that socialism can only be built through mass participation and control by the working class — the masses of ordinary people. In “The State and Revolution” Lenin had said that the proletariat needs to smash up the old bureaucratic state in all its components and build a new form of governance. But this is not what the Bolsheviks did. They insisted at the Soviet Congress of October 1917 that a new state cabinet of ministers under control of their leaders be created — the Council of People’s Commissar. But this was really quite similar in its structure — and in many of the personnel at various levels — to the cabinet of ministers under the Provisional government, which had been modeled on the tsarist regime. Each of the positions in the Council of People’s Commissars had control over a “commissariat” which was like a conventional bureaucratic ministry. They created the new state planning body from above, Supreme Council of National Economy. This was made up of Bolshevik stalwarts, and various bureaucrats and experts. In setting up their regional and industrial planning administration they simply took over the glavki which were the industrial planning bureaucracies of the old tsarist regime. Lenin was totally opposed to the councils being mostly elected by workers. Lenin’s concept of “worker control” never got beyond his idea that worker committees would monitor and maybe check or veto management on certain issues, but there would still be power in the hands of management. Even as late as 1931, Trotsky was still defining “worker control” is this very weak and narrow way. The Bolsheviks seem to have inherited a lot of their programmatic weaknesses from the pre-World War 1 social democratic Marxism. The idea that socialism would be something akin to the German post office — as Lenin put it in “The State and Revolution.” So consequently, with their fixation on control through this central state apparatus, they did not emphasize mass participation in control of neighborhoods and workplaces by working class people. This is in fact the key explanation as to why the revolution got consolidated into a bureaucratic ruling class. We don’t have to make any assumptions of personal vices like “being power hungry” to explain the outcome.

Unfortunately for him, Chomsky is almost totally ignorant of Lenin and Leninism. Lenin was no tyrant nor was he a ‘power-hungry’ opportunist. All his political life he was, like Marx, a supporter of working class power and radical democracy; hence his slogan “All power to the soviets!” (the soviets were working class factory councils set up after the popular February 1917 revolution). Lenin opposed an insurrection against the hopeless Kerensky regime (that had been set up after the above popular revolution — and which was ripe for overthrow by a counter-revolution, probably spearheaded by General Kornilov, which would have restored the Tsar) until the Bolshevik Party had won majority support in the soviets. The subsequent October insurrection (old calendar) was an essential move in order to stop the above counter-revolution succeeding, which would have been followed by a bloodbath (like the one that followed the Paris Commune 46 years earlier, when 30,000 men, women and children were summarily executed). The Paris Commune of 1871 The counter-revolution, which began soon after the insurrection, took the form of a civil war, which the Bolsheviks had to fight ruthlessly or face the aforementioned bloodbath. Chomsky ignores this salient fact in his ahistorical criticism of Lenin and the Bolsheviks. Apparently, he thinks that harsh language, stern looks and a few letters to the editor would have been sufficient to stop the 13 invading imperialist armies, not to mention the White Army itself. An extended defence of Lenin and the Bolsheviks can be accessed here: In Defence of Lenin and the October Revolution See also: The Russian civil war ============================ Any critics of the above are encouraged to read the polite warning I have added to the foot of the following answer of mine before they think to respond: Why-did-socialism-fail-in-Russia/answer/Rosa-Lichtenstein
